/btg/ BOOT GENERAL - HANDSEWN SEASON SOON EDITION

What do I need to care for my boots?
>Old cotton t shirt (one for cleaning, another for applying conditioners)
>Horsehair brush ($10-15)
>Wooden shoe trees ($10-15)
>Light conditioner like Lexol/Bck4/renovateur
>Heavy conditioner (if you live in terrible snow/rain areas) Sno seal/Obernauf LP
>Don't forget that boots need time to dry properly, rotate them and don't wear them daily for too long

How do I deal with x stain?
>mud: allow it to dry then brush off
>salt: water and cloth as soon as possible
>saturated wet: allow the boot to dry for a full day, stuff with newspaper
>scuffs and scratches: buff vigorously with horsehair brush

>Should I buy turdsdays/soloshits/doc shitans?
No they are filled with synthetic materials aimed at instant comfort but will not hold up to actual use.
>b-b-but muh ecelebs on youtube said they're good
no. you will waste your time and money and still have uncomfortable footwear at the end of the day. spend the extra $100 and get something real.

Manufacturer Red Flags
>Luxury
>Sustainable
>Vegan
>Unknown leather source
>Made in Chyna/Mexico/Indonesia

Boot Red Flags
>Dainite
>Zippers
>Non gusseted tongues
>Excessive/unnecessary seams

If you're talking about building a wardrobe out of stuff you can't afford, just look for cheaper versions. In this day and age you can find almost any item in every price range.

If you're talking about one specific item, save for it. It might take you longer than you wanted, but it'll be worth it.

But maybe the first thing is to reevaluate why you want something. I've been guilty -and still am, sometimes- of vapid consumerism when buying something more for the thrill of getting ot than from actually wearing the item later.
I've been tempted to get rid of most of my stuff and keep a minimalistic wardrobe, but more often than not can't part with stuff even if I've not worn it for long and probably won't wear it ever again.

This is completely wrong.
pre-natal T affects primarily brain development in the embryo and in infancy, especially high or low T in the womb is associated with abnormal sexual development and alternative gender identities
post-natal T affects physical characteristics after puberty.
regular T affects muscle growth, bone growth, fertility, and sex drive
the DHT metabolite (other major form of T in humans) affects genital growth, hair growth (balding on the head, body hair growth), and is the key male neurosteroid, driving behaviors like aggression and competition.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17481745
There are people out there that used water-based washing fluids like deox-007, but you have to be careful to immediately dry/rinse the parts. I don't want to think about that so have stayed away from aqueous solutions for watches, but have used that for cleaning a clock movement where it's easier to dry the parts immediately with a compressed air stream.
I stay away from anything ammoniated; I tried that first and noticed it pulled some of the copper out of surface of the parts. Did some research after that and found that it embrittles the metal on prolonged exposure, so switched to plain naphtha.

posts.com:
>>17479732
>>17479820
Retinoids should be used at night not because they make your skin sensitive to UV, but because the retinoid itself is sensitive to UV and will become chemically unstable/break down before it's able to work if exposed to daylight. (And temperature. Keep your retinoid/retinol products in the fridge where possible. Otherwise a dark drawer or cupboard.)

Morning:
>Cleanse.
>Toner (pref. Korean or otherwise astringent free.)
>Active serum (if applicable.)
>Moisturizer/cream (your hyaluronic acid/niacinamide cream.)
>Sunscreen.
Night:
>Cleanse.
>Toner.
>Retinol/Retinoid product. Leave for 10-15 minutes to fully absorb.
>Serum.
>Moisturizer/cream.

Once a week take a break from the retinol to use a clay mask and then a hydrating mask (substitute the retinoid's place in your routine and use the other products as normal.)

If you use an off-the-shelf retinol/retinoid product, you can still use a chemical exfoliant like AHA once a week, also. Don't do this with a prescription strength retinoic acid.

If you find your skin is very sensitive at the beginning, ease into the retinoid by using it every second day, then two days on/one day off, and build up to using it every day. It can help.


>>17479842
Wash your pillowcase every week, pay attention to what touches your face during the day, consider a new shampoo/conditioner and your diet. Excess sugars fuck with your hormones and skin.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17479826
Just because I forgot to tag (you) specifically: Yes. Once a week replace the retinol with a ~10% lactic acid solution. This will go a lot better for your skin if you wash with a microfibre cloth and avoid ever swiping/scrubbing your face with a towel. Always pat, because once you introduce this level of chemical exfoliant you want to avoid physical exfoliation as much as possible.

I find that a thick wash-off mask with a strong anti-inflammatory active ingredient really helps once you have this level of exfoliation happening. The Some By Mi Propolis B5 mask is my favourite. An anti-inflammatory sleeping pack would probably be great, too.

There's a lot of great gentler exfoliants out there. The Ordinary's Glycolic acid is really good. Lactic Acid 10% is also great and even gentler. You don't need to use such a harsh exfoliant anyway because you're already exfoliating the skin when you shave. Just stick to something gentler. I'm taking one for the team:

Okay, let's make it simple!

To dress like a gentleman, you want to wear clothes that look polished and put-together. That means avoiding anything too casual, like ripped jeans or athletic wear.

Here's what you can wear for different occasions:

A casual day out:
For a more relaxed look, you can wear a pair of chinos (a type of pants), a button-down shirt, and some sneakers or loafers.

Office workday:
For a more professional look, you can wear a dress shirt, a tie, dress pants, and dress shoes. A blazer or a suit jacket can also be added for extra formality.

Formal events:
For a formal event, you can wear a suit (jacket and pants made from the same material), a dress shirt, a tie, and dress shoes.

To shop for these clothes, you can visit men's clothing stores in your local mall or online retailers that sell men's clothing. Look for brands that are known for producing high-quality, timeless clothing.

Remember, dressing like a gentleman is not just about what you wear, but also how you wear it. Make sure your clothes fit you well, and that you feel comfortable in them. With a little bit of effort, you'll be able to dress like a gentleman in no time!

casual smart is one of the easiest styles to pull off and you don't need to spend outrageous amounts of money to pull it off. things to avoid:
>jeans
>sneakers
>anything with a hood
>short sleeved button ups
for pants, chinos are always a good pick. they can easily be dressed up or down and are readily available. for shirts, button ups and polos are your friend. for long armed button ups, spend some time trying to find ones that fit you well. if you have an athletic frame, go for flattering but never tight. make sure they fall nicely when tucked in to your pants. i can't stress enough how important proper sizing is for button ups. polos are less sensitive to that. over your shirt, wool sweaters are a great choice. troyers and v necks allow the collar to stand naturally with the uppermost button undone giving you a more sporty, casual appearance. troyers are more sporty than v-necks. crew necks will give collars a more restrained look. be careful with that, it can make you look very boyish depending on how masculine you look to begin with and the type of collar you wear. i prefer wool sweaters over cotton. for shoes, i like chucka boots. leather boots in general will work. if you live in the city, you can easily do dress shoes too.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17481853
>Pls explain like I'm a baby how to dress like a gentleman
ok
>not being too casual but still gentleman like
The word you're looking for is business casual
>Classy and timeless is the goal
Shirt, sweater, trousers, tie is optional, no jeans, loafers or leather shoes, only minimalist sneakers.
No oversized or undersized clothes. There are no compromises on that point. Don't buy stuff unless you're 100% sure it fits your body type.
The rest is mostly about having a clean presentation. Clean shaven or tidy beard, combed hair or a fresh haircut and cologne. No wrinkles on your shirts either and keep your collar straight.
As for accessories, belt and shoes should preferably match, but it's not gospel. If you're wearing a leather watch it should match the belt. Heraldry rings can be classy touch but keep all jewelry minimalistic.
Learn color matching. Don't wear too many bright colors at once. When buying clothes I'd recommend going more for subtle colors as it's typically easier to match them with other items. Color matching will be learned mostly through experience but there are multiple tutorials on YouTube for the basics.
>What to wear
Really depends on the season, weather, location and time of day. Maybe this sounds simplistic or maybe this is confusing, take it however you want. It should come pretty naturally though. Darker colors in winter, brighter colors in summer. Sweaters for colder weather, coats for wind or rain. Brighter shades throughout the day, darker shades for evenings (typically). Shades of grey for formal wear and cities, brown for friends and family and the countryside. You should have a everyday cologne and an evening cologne. Same goes for colognes that match the seasons. None of this is gospel and you can mix it up quite a bit, but try to match the vibe of where you're going to a certain extent.
(Pt. 1)

Wearing Revealing Clothing Isn’t Asserting Your Freedom
I’m a feminist who is against crop-tops and revealing clothing (and I’m writing this as someone who loves crop tops). Far from being some kind of cranky old woman with antiquated values, I think women wearing just a bit more clothing is a big part of the solution to sexism.
The reason I think this is simple.
When women wear less clothing, we are giving misogynists exactly what they want.
It serves misogynists for feminists to think that being scantily clad is an expression of freedom. It gives misogynists exactly what they want—consequence-free access to female bodies. (Hookup culture serves them in the same way). By making it easier for misogynists to access sex, we reinforce their misogyny. They go to their other male friends and spread it, and on the cycle continues.
If getting naked were really the answer to gender relation problems, men would be doing it too. But we are not seeing a sudden popularity spike in the male crop-top, nor are we seeing any other kind of male-revealing clothing become popular.
Every year, women are wearing less and less clothing while men continue wearing the same amount of clothes as ever.
And look, I get it. When I go out, I feel the same pressure to be the sexiest bitch at the bar that every other woman does. My eyes rake over the most attractive women in public, measuring myself against them. (They didn’t start doing this until I started competing for male attention).
But we have to ask ourselves: Where does this lead? Women walking around in bikinis and fishnet while men are still wearing their suits?
Go ahead, picture it.

Is that the equality we dreamed of?

AM:
Rinse face with water (do not dry)
Cetaphil cleanser applied to damp face
Rinse face with water (do not dry)
Cetaphil moisturizer applied to do face
Any SPF 50+ sunscreen once face has dried

PM:
Rinse face with water (do not dry)
Cetaphil cleanser applied to damp face
Rinse face with water (dry it this time)
Apply tretinoin (no, it is not too harsh)
Wait 15 minutes
Wet hands, apply Cetaphil moisturizer

This will get you 90% to the best skincare routines, and the cost is cents per day.

Other tips:
Do not touch your face unless you wash your hands.
Do not let a used towel touch your face.
Buy 10 of the cheapest cotton pillow slips (they are usually less than a dollar each) and change nightly.
Drink enough water.
When you are in the sun, wear a hat.
Remember that leathery skin is your body's way of protecting itself from sun, that means good looking skin is inherently more vulnerable to sun, beware the sun.

>>17471918
Let’s not get lost in the weeds. First off I think you have to be more specific, and carve just the northeast portion off the USA and compare only that part to the UK. Otherwise it’s not a fair comparison at all because the rest of the country is a mess fashion wise, and yes that ESPECIALLY includes LA and Miami (you can’t buy class). With that out of the way, the UK is still the clear winner. Hopefully this doesn’t offend American anons, but I think it’s just because the USA is a younger country and hasn’t reached the same level of civilization yet. American style is simple and utilitarian. Think Ralph Lauren, Brooks Brothers etc. This is actually more aligned with my own personal style. Old Europe is just gay to me. America hasn’t gone through as many cycles of decadence as older countries have. I think this is changing and you can see it in things like the craft beer trend, “foodie culture”, and increased wine and quality cheese production in the USA. Previously, Americans only ate to survive and wore clothes to cover their nakedness and not an ounce of thought went into the details beyond this. There was important work to do.
In contrast, the UK has been doing this fashion stuff for a while. Look at how swagged out Henry the 8th was, pic related, and then compare that to boring old George Washington’s dress. Yes he was a royal but even British working class scum are more fashion conscious than their lowly counterparts across the pond. See the tidy and thoughtfully curated fits of the skinheads, or the expensive wardrobes of the ‘casuals’ soccer hooligan subculture…

posts.com:

I don’t think you would catch many Walmart workers in America paying $100+ for their polo shirts (unless they’re black). Fashion is just not that important to them and in fact they’re likely to consider any type of shirt with a collar to be uppity and bourgeois. Best to save their pennies for meth. Add to the subcultures I mentioned above mods, rockers, teddy boys, punk, goth, new wave, rave, etc etc. There’s just far more examples of Brits traditionally putting more thought, effort, and pride into what they wear.

HISTORY
IS A MYSTERY .. errr.... So here's why;

Linen use to be all of our underwear, undershirts/shirts and anything that touched the body (caps, corsets were lined in it). But then America started growing cotton ENMASS and the price of cotton went from higher then linen to DIRT cheaper then linen.

We also typically use different looms for linen then cotton to weave the fabric. So as cotton exploded in demand we replaced all of our linen-possessing equipment with cotton-oriented equipment. And now cotton is being slowly replaced by plastic because poly is now the new cheap thing.

>Hiking
Get some lace-to-toe leather boots instead of combat boots. Your feet will thank you. The ability to choose the lacing the whole way up the foot is a huge plus.

They're more expensive for sure, but you pay for more boot. They'll typically last longer and take more punishment. Danner makes the Mountain Light hiking boots, which are ~$400. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17477879
The mistake you're making is wearing the same pair of footwear 24/7 and expecting them to be fine. They won't.
You need at least two pairs in a rotation, or 3 if you really have a acid monkey sweat problem. Some people do as their body chemistry is overwhelmingly low ph for some reason.
Two/three pairs of whatever, when you take off a pair let it dry for a bit, longer if you're in a cold and wet environs where things don't try easily on their own, then slip in some shoe/boot trees. Cedar wood preferred. The next day you DON'T wear that pair, and instead wear the other pair. Repeat the cycle.
Avoid leather soles if you're worried about speedy wear. Shouldn't use leather soles in wet conditions anyway as they deteriorate 10x faster when wet.
Get more than one pair of whatever it is.
